SUMMARY: XapR, xanthosine phosphorylase regulator, activates transcription of genes involved in xanthosine metabolism when xanthosine is present [10400599, 7559336]. Deoxyinosine can also induce XapR activity, although not to same extent as xanthosine [10400599]. XapR, which belongs to LysR family, has a DNA-binding site in N-terminal domain [2201776] and a signal-recognition site separated in two regions in amino acid sequence. In three-dimensional structure of an XapR homolog (CysB from Klebsiella aerogenes), se two regions appear close to each or, forming one signal-binding site. XapR is homologous to AlsR; y show 68% of identity in an amino-terminal region of 60 amino acids [10400599]. xapR gene is located downstream of genes it regulates and in same direction, but in an independent transcription unit that appears to be expressed constitutively [7559336].
